dialogues.speaker: EXT, THEATRE
dialogues.text: Glamorous opening night crowds arriving at a hit show; limousines discharging women in furs, men in tuxedos, Flashbulbs pop for celebrity arrivals, CHIMES announce curtain time, the lobby lights blink invitingly. We MOVE IN cn this, a3 if arriving for the show, only to PAN OFF TO an alley alongside th2 theatre, where a squalid derelict lies half-conscious against the wall, hands clutching a ratty paper bag wrapped’ around a bottle of Muscatel, meager belong- ings crammed into a battered old suitcase tied with clothesline and a necktie.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUM
dialogues.text: It's NAVIN, red-eyed and whiskered, the bottom of the barrel. He looks directly INTO CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: My story...? I have not always been like this. I once had wealth, power, and the love of a beautiful woman. Now, I only have two things... My dignity... and my pride... A janitor hoses the alley down directly spraying Navin.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing; recovering) It was never easy for me... MUSIC OPTICAL EFFECTS begin to lead us into a FLASH- BACK.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) .«». I was born a-poor black child... ‘ RIPPLE DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lazy Sunday afternoon, and a black family (MOTHER, FATHER, grandma, and eight children ranging from 24 to 7 years of age) are quietly absorbed in routine tasks. Two black men, Uncle Sonny and Cousin * Brownie play a rousing gospel type song and the family joins in; some of the others keep time and play harmonic: Navin, dressed and placed as one of the family, is noddin happily out of tempo. When the blues finishes, he is the only one to applaud. As he looks around sheep-~ ishly: |

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The familv is at dinner, Mother is serving.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Here's cornbread, and greens, and some of those hog maws you like, and leave room for some sweet potato pie...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Mother, ain't you forgettin' something?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Not at all -- listen, everybody, today is Navin's birthday and I cooked him up his favorite meal... The family reacts with joy and enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Gee, Mom -- thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (producing a tray) : Tunafish salad on white bread with mayonnaise, a Tab, and a couple of Twinkies... | The Twinkies have candles stuck through the cellophane. Everyone sings as Navin gets his birthday meal.

dialogues.speaker: TAS
dialogues.text: Mmm-mmm -- I know you're gonna like that shit. : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oo

dialogues.speaker: ELVIRA
dialogues.text: (age twelve) Here, Navin -- I made it in school... She gives him a little leather wallet.

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: i got you somethin’ too...A half bottle of Lilac Vegetal. I got it at an estate saie. He hands Navin an unwrapped bottle. The others press around with inexpensive, sincere gifts, including the littlest kid's contribution, a grade-school crayon family portrait: nine black faces and one conspicuously blank white one. ~

dialogues.speaker: . FAMILY
dialogues.text: (AD LIB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are... This is for you .-. Hope you like it... etc.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN , 5
dialogues.text: He is overwhelmed by this generosity. NAVIN. Thank you... thank you... God bless us, every one... His eyes fill with tears, and he bolts from the table, disappearing into a bedroom,

dialogues.speaker: . TAI
dialogues.text: What's the matter now?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIRA
dialogues.text: Momma, why's Navin crying? MOTHER . Because you all made him so happy. Eat your dinner. I'11l talk to him... She goes in after him, carrying the Twinkies. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT, BOYS' BEDROOM
dialogues.text: There are three beds in the room. Navin is lying on the quilt, sobbing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Aw, Mom, I'm sorry I spoiled the party... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They hug.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I brought your Twinkie.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You feelin' ‘different’ again?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: It's like I don't belong here, like I don't fit in.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Son, it's your birthday, and it's time you knew. You ain't our naturel-born child.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You was left on our doorstep, and we vaised you like you was one of us.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: You mean I'm going to stay this eclor... ughhh.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, son, I'd love you if you was the color of a baboon's ass. Navin is hugging his Mom, trying to absorb this information. Taj, the eldest, sticks his head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: TAI
dialogues.text: I wrapped your sandwich in cellophane, just how you like it. ~ You wanna come in and sing some blues?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: No thanks. There's something about those songs, they -- they depress me. , Taj exits, and a moment later we HEAR the family launch into a full Mississippi Delta rural BLUES. Mom leaves Navin and goes to join then,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is lying in the middle of a double bed with his four black brothers. In the background we can HEAR the RADIO PLAYING.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... And that concludes this Sunday night Gospel Hour, live from the Four Square Gospel Church of Divine Salvation in St. Louis, Missouri, the Reverend Willard * Willman, Pastor. Navin stares into the night. The program changes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And now, Musit Throughout the Night; music in a mellow mood. One of the Fifties’ most forgettable standards in a stupid Lawrence Welk Society Orchestra arrangement. Navin looks up, caught by something. It's his theme, his music. The rhythm continues, Navin begins to snap his fingers and tap his foot, this time definitely on the beat. He climbs over his brothers, and glides into the liv~ ing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music has shifted to another danceable 4/4 FOX- TROT. Navin is box-stepping and dipping like crazy. The light goes on from his parents' bedroom, and his Mother, sleepy in curlers and nightdress, emerges. Others in the family wake up to see what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: What in the hell is that noise? MOTHER. Navin ~- is that -you?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Elvira, Leroy, Mom, Dad, Satch, Pierre... Listen! This is a music I've never heard before! Listen to itl] It speaks to me. Oh, T know there's life out there... It's the kind of music that tells me to go out there and be somebody! Che sings) YOU... STOLE MY HEART AWAY... YOU... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER .
dialogues.text: But Navin...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (sighs) Let him go.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: What happened? Come on back. I know you out there. Come on back. They stare at him in amazement as he waltzes around the room in ecstasy, and we... FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SIDE OF HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: Navin and Dad stop behind the house.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Son, now that you're goin' out in the world, there's somethin' you should know. See that? (he points to the ground) That's shit. (he reaches in his pocket . and takes out a can) And this is Shinola.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Shit...Shinola.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Son, you gonna be ali right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is bidding his family goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: And remember -- the Lord loves a working man.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Lord loves a working man. *

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: And, son, don't never, ever trust Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Don't trust Whitey. Lord * loves a working man. Don't trust Whitey. Daddy. Pierre, don't forget to grow up.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Let the boy go. We got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I hope you find whatever it is you're lookin’ for, son.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I will -- I know it's out there.

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: (takes Navin aside) It's out there and if you catch it, go to a doctor and get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Taj. Grandma. Hugs and kisses all around. Profound, sincere fare- wells. This is goodbye. Navin steps away, and walks proudly out through the garden gate. Then he stands in the road, puts out his thumb, and waits for a hitch. The family stands around patiently, then, one by one, drift off -- the kids to school, Pop to work, Mom into the house. Navin waits, and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is seated around the dinner table eating their dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I sho' do miss Navin... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELVIRA
dialogues.text: Is he ever comin' back?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Take his place settin' away... it's makin’ us too goddamn sad!

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: I'll take his... (grabs a ear of corn from platter)

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (wearily) I wonder if he's doin’ all right? Elvira gets up from the table and goes to the window and shouts outside.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIRA
dialogues.text: How you doin', Navin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is still standing in the same spot.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I'm okay!... Don't worry about me. I think I see a car coming!... Oh... wait!... No, it's a truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, take care of our little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dilapidated farm truck has just stopped in front of Navin. It is driven by an elderly FARMER.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: How far you goin', son?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: St. Louis. How far are you going?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: (pointing) Well, I'm just goin' up to that fence there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We SEE a fence which is about twelve feet by where Navin is standing. Navin debates for a moment -- he throws his bag into the truck and hops in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck starts up and begins to roll.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) ’ Hil... I'm Navin Johnson... What's your name, sir?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Well, here we are. Navin gets out of the truck and retrieves his bag. As the truck drives off and makes a right turn, Navin shouts: NAVIN . Thanks for the company!... I hope I can repay you someday! : Navin turns back toward the road and puts his thumb out.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN ON THE ROAD 15
dialogues.text: . thru -- Getting a lift with a big semi. 18 -- Hitching in the rain. -- Trudging down an empty Uighway, a large city in the distance. Getting out of a car in a downtown area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign outside reads: "FIREBIRD MOTEL"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is pleased with his room; it's sparse, but clean. What a bargain! He walks over to the window and pulls the drapes open. A ROARING 747 flies towards his face. At the last moment, it gains altitude and skims over the roof of the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is sound asleep. We HEAR a SCRATCHING at the door, then a DOG BARKING. Navin wakes; he hears it, too. The barking becomes more insistent. Navin goes to the door and opens it. There is a dog, barking frantically.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: What is it, boy?...,Trouble?... Well, what is it?... An accident?... The dog growls negatively.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... A drowning?... The dog growls negatively again.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) A fire! The dog barks excitedly. Navin rushes into the room and collects his belongings.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've heard about dogs like youl. You're gonna get your picture in the paper...You're gonna be famous. Come on, we got to warn everybody!... Gosh...this is exciting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin runs to a door and pounds.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Wooft... Woof!... I... I mean fire! Fire! There's a fire! He continues to run down the hall knocking on doors, shouting "Fire!" The motel doors begin to open and people start exiting from their rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin and the dog stand as the motel empties out: hookers, Shriners, tourists, salesmen, etc. They assemble in the parking lot in front of the motel. Navin bends down to talk to the dog. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Who do you belong to pooch? * Navin reads the tage.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) There's no name...You don't * belong to anybody...It just says you're allergic to penicillin... Well, I'll give you a name, Lifesaver...You saved ail these lives... The dog puts his head down.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're going to be my dog, Lifesaver!

dialogues.speaker: FIRST TOURIST
dialogues.text: Hey!... There's no fire!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND TOURIST
dialogues.text: Whe yelled fire?!

dialogues.speaker: THIRD TOURIST
dialogues.text: I was sound asleep!

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH TOURIST
dialogues.text: I was watching T.V.!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I was taking a shower! The crowd grumbles and returns inside the motel.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY LADY
dialogues.text: That's a nice dog, mister. What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, him?... Shithead. (walks away and turns back to dog) C'mon, Shithead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck pulls up, drops off Navin and the dog. They head for the office.  rev. 5/79 ll.

dialogues.speaker: INT GAS STATION OFFICE
dialogues.text: An older man, HARRY HARTOUNIAN, the imigrant owner of this station, is stacking cans of engine additive.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: {mopping} Hey: Where're you goin?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: To the bathroom. ‘ BARRY * You need a key.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Oh! Can I get one?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: No, it's only for customers who by gas.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I'm buyin' gas.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I don't see your car.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I just need enough for my lighter.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: And my wife didn't want me to come in today. I would have missed a whole lighter fill up. It's hanging on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Thanks. (Gets key)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN 26
dialogues.text: with difficulty, drags the brake drum and unlocks the deor to the restroom and enters it. We HEAR the SOUND of Navin PEEING. Harry stands by the door and yells at Navin.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Hey... pap top!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Huh?... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Hey... silverbird! I'm talking to you. Navin continues peeing.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You want to be president of Texaco

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sure!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Clean up the sink in there!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then I'll be president of Texaco 011?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (mimicking) Then I'll be president... Whatever happened to working your way up? Kids today!... They don't want to start at the bottom and work their way up... they want to start at the top and work their way sideways! You're not working here ten minutes and already you want to be president!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But, sir, I don't work here.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (cunning) Oh, not even for... a dollar-ten an hour? The bathroom door opens slowly and we SEE Navin staring in disbelief. :

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Wha... you'll pay me $1.10 if I work here an hour?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You betcha.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (catching on) What if I work two hours? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Then I pay you $2.20. Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: What about eight hours?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: What about fourteen and one-half hours?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAVIN ¢ What about nine and three-quarters?...

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: What about eighteen hours and twenty- six min...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Look!... However long you work, I pay you $1.10 an hour. (pointing) See that mop, see that bucket, you know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir! Navin proceeds to mop the inside of the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin mopping the garage floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hour later. Navin approaches Harry at the register.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I's been an hour. You owe me $1.10.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (repeating, patiently) * It's been an hour, so you owe me a dollar and ten cents.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Oh. He fishes in register, gives Navin a dollar and a dime. Navin thanks him, and sprints back to work, happy at his new job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin working like a demon, washing, polishing, stack- ing, straightening. Every now and again he checks the clock on the wall. Each hour, he approaches Harry for another hour's wages. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Look. I tell you what. Instead of paying you $1.10 every hour... Navin gives him a suspicious look. Is Whitey trying to cut his wages?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You keep track of how many hours you work, and I'll pay you at the end of the week.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Let me ge this straight. You'll Pay me or every hour I work in a wee (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Sure. Harry nods appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Fifty, sixty, even seventy hours? $1.10 for each hour?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Navin indicates "This is a great deal -- This old man must be nuts...'’ They shake hands on it. “WAVIN Remember -- as many hours as I want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is on a ladder, hanging what is obviously his own hand-lettered sign -- "OPEN ALL NIGHT."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is posting a letter at a mailbox across the way from the gas station. He turns and sprints back to the gas station as we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "Dear Mom, I got this great job in a gas station. I don't want to say just how much I'm getting, but let's just say it's a lot. I'm enclosing two dollars... The following should fade down as the next comes up:

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) . '... it's a lot of fim working and Mr. Hartounian is really nice. He is teaching me how to be impatient. Well, I've got to go now. What do you think I do?... Write letters all day? Your loving son, Navin.'  rev. 3/12 16. 33“ OMITTED 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin crosses to a dolly that slides under a car. On it are a blanket and a small pillow which he makes up as a bed. dartounian enters.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: How come you got no place to stay?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted to get a decorator first..., and the carpeting I want just isn't available now...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (gently) Navin, you're the son I've always wanted, and I'm glad I didn't get him because now that I see it... I don't want it... Come with me. They start to walk.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're just like me, a dreamer... Fifty years ago I come to this country with nothing. Today I got this gas station, a little split-level in the suburbs and a telephone. People call me up... Hello, Mr. Hartounian, it's a pleasure to talk to you on the phone. Navin follows Harry into the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man is at the urinal.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Navin -- I'm gonna give you a nice place to stay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: This is fabulous. I can put the kitchen over here...And I'll put up a wall...it'll give the impression of two rooms.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Mot this. In there: Harry opens a door in the back wall of the toilet.  36 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. Harry turns on a naked light bulb and illuminates a bare storage room... oil, batteries and car parts are stored.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: It's a great place -- nce kitchen, no bathroom, no windows; it's a masterpiece of understatement... I'll put a bed in here, a bigger bulb... I'll bring some sheets > from home and you're set for life.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Cosh! How much will it cost me? “HARRY , Nothing. Someday when you're rich and famous, you'll send me a postcard. Navin thinks it over... Finally:

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: A postcard, huh? Well, okay, it's a deal. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (takes out a pencil) Navin, you're a good boy... I'm writing something down here... I'm going to put it in this little envelope... (does so and hands it to Navin) ... and someday when you're at the bottom of the barrel and the bottom starts to fall out... And you can't stand the pain and you feel like you're walking around with your pants around your ankles, you open this up and you'll read something that'll take the pain away.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (looks at envelope) Thanks, Harry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Navin turns and hits his head on a jutting beam. He screams, plops onto a crate and starts opening the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What're you doing? He grabs the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: * I'm in pain.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You don't waste wisdom like this for a pain like that. He stuffs the envelope in Navin's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Save this for a big pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: neatly furnished in gas station leftover: chairs made from tires, crates, jacks holding up a table- for. etc. Navin is staring at a new phone. SOUND: NG. Navin lets it RING four or five times.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (runs to door and shouts out) Mr. Hartounian! It's working! It's ringing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY — I know. I rang you... Can I hang up now?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No... Let me see if the talking part works...  39 394 40 Al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin runs back to the phone and gingerly picks up the receiver and stares into it at arms length.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hello, hello... Mister, I'm talking to you!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Harry, it works great! It's . unbelievable... It’s a miracle! It sounds like you're in the next room. Harry, I owe you so much.

dialogues.speaker: -. HARRY
dialogues.text: No. I owe you. At last I know the true meaning of the word shmuck.

dialogues.speaker: 39A
dialogues.text: 40 41 Navin is stacking new oil cans out of cartons and put- ting them in a rack., Harry and his wife, a gorgeous 30-year-old, voluptuous blonde, drive up in their new Impala to the gas pump. Harry gets out of the car to talk to Navin.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Mr. Hartounian, you said you weren't going to come in today.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I want to show you something... Look at this... . (points to wife in car) . Navin, this is my wife, Lenore.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you... Harry has told me so little about you.

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARRY

dialogues.text: I didn't want to get spit on me. He takes her head in his hands and moves it toward him for a kiss. She strains to pull away from him; she tightens her mouth into a thin line and all the muscles in her neck strain to pull away. They are deadlocked. They fall over panting from the strain. They rest for a moment and start up again, going through a shorter version ending up exhausted on the sand.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Was it good for you too?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I really do want to kiss you, but I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, I would've kept my tongue in.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: No, I mean I'm afraid if I kiss you I'll fall in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: You would?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: And I don't want to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: My mother sacrificed everything to send me through cosmetology school.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: She did?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: She has a dream for me to be something. To marry somecne with power... money... vision... somecne with & special purpose.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (elated) I got one! I've got a special purpose! He rises.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is great. Your Mom's going to love me. This is fantastic. And I was afraid to tell you about it: He pulls her up. She looks at him with love and com- passion, takes him and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is staring at the ceiling. Marie is dozing next to him. Navin turns toward Marie, rises on his elbow and stares down at the lovely face that is lit by a shaft of moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (softly) Marie, are you :awake? (no answer) Good. You look so beautiful and peaceful... you almost look dead. And I'm glad because I want to say something that has always been very hard for me to say -- Rubber Baby Buggy Bumpers. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've never been relaxed enouzh around people to be able to say that. You give me confidence in myself. I've decided that tomorrow when the time is right, I'm going to ask you to marry me. If that's okay with you, just don't answer... She sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You've made meso happy. He curls up next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is luxuriating in a bubble bath.. . the water is running...

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (singing) I'LL SEE YOU AGAIN, “by Noel Coward. We HEAR MARIE 0.S. from the bedroom, SINGING with him.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Honey, who's the happiest guy in the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie, dressed, is sitting at a desk writing. Shit- head is lying on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN .
dialogues.text: That's right. And who's the happiest gal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie turns, her eyes brimming with tears. She opens her mouth to answer but can't... In her hand is a letter she is in the process of folding.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's right! (sings) I'M PICKING OUT A ‘THERMOS FOR YOU... Marie puts the letter in an envelope, slides it under the bathroom door... picks up 4 packed valise, stops for a moment to look at the bathroom, then turns and leaves quietly, as Navin continues singing.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: '... AND A CUP BUILT RIGHT IN.'
dialogues.text: (speaks) Honey, there's a question I'd like to pop but I've been afraid ... that you might say no... But this seems like the right time and place... so here goes! Honey, will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shithead at open front decor, growls.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (splashes happily) yahoo! C'mon in here and let's seal it with a kiss... Get in the tub with me!... This ‘only happens once in a lifetime. into the tub! C'mon, honey, Shithead comes dashing into the room and leaps into the tub.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing; sweetly) Not you, Shithead. Where's Marie? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHITHEAD
dialogues.text: (Barks)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: What letter? Navin sees the letter lying in a puddle of water. He opens it and reads silently. .

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, noll!

dialogues.speaker: THE LETTER 158
dialogues.text: is a runny blur. Only "Dear Navin" and intermittent words are legible.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (reads the blurry letters in blurry double talk) Dear Navin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin gets out of the tub, shielding his private parts by holding Shithead in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (shouts) Marie! He races out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin, naked, holding Shithead in front of him, spots a stray dog. .

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (whistles) C'mon, boy! He picks up dog, covers his behind with him and runs down the street shouting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Marie! Marie! did you leave me? I couldn't x the letter it was too blurry!!!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MIDWAY
dialogues.text: Navin is stand. in fx: a fast- spinning thrill ride like the is running it. Ir's early in the day and there ze only a few people on the midway and on the ride.

dialogues.speaker: HUSKY
dialogues.text: You want what?_

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I just need someplace where i can think.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROUND-UP 162
dialogues.text: Navin is alone in a reflective mood, spinning wildly. INTERCUT several shots of passengers getting on and off the ride. Husky, each time, checks to see if Navin wishes to disembark... each time Navin shakes his head no...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MIDWAY
dialogues.text: He watches Navin spin.

dialogues.speaker: FROSTY
dialogues.text: (to Husky) What time did he start?

dialogues.speaker: HUSKY
dialogues.text: Ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: FROSTY
dialogues.text: (checks his watch) Six hours... He really has it bad for her. It only took Richard Burton four hours up there to forget Liz Taylor...  164 165

dialogues.speaker: ROUND-UP . 164
dialogues.text: It slow to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: HUSKY
dialogues.text: (amazed) He wants off... (calls) Baldo, Iggy, peel nim off! Baldo and Igzy go te fetch Navin. They are a pair of not-too-bright "CARNIES" who have been standing with a group of other slow-witted carnival workers.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN 165
dialogues.text: as“Baldo and Iggy carry him off and set him in front of Frosty and the group. Navin is a wreck. His hair standing out like a porcupine. His face is dirty and covered with perspiration. All the bizarre looking carnies are staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (with raging emotion) What are you looking at? Haven't you ever seen a man so broken that he had to spin? I went through every emotion up there... from anger to... to... What's another emotion?

dialogues.speaker: BALDO
dialogues.text: Fear?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: IGGY
dialogues.text: Hate?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (shouts) Hate!... Oh do I hate!... And I went through... uh... uh... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HUSKY
dialogues.text: Hunger?

dialogues.speaker: DOODLES
dialogues.text: Hunger ain't an emotion.

dialogues.speaker: HUSKY
dialogues.text: Is love one?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Yes, love!... I went from anger to hate to love... to... to... uh “SLATS (real dumb- looking guy) Ennui...?

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Yeah, ennui?... How about ennui?... What about pride?... Or prejudice? . Sloth?... Adultery...?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... Wait a minute! (pulls out letter and waves it) I don't have to know what this letter says... I've got to make me worthy of her... Look at me! Iggy, would you want to marry me and have my children?

dialogues.speaker: IGGY
dialogues.text: No. NAVIN . Well, I'm going to make something of myself. :

dialogues.speaker: IGGY
dialogues.text: Well, maybe then...

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Right now, I'm nothing: (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm a fly speck... a... a gmat... a... a...

dialogues.speaker: IGGY
dialogues.text: A stink buq.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Yeah... I'm a...a...

dialogues.speaker: SLATS
dialogues.text: A pimple on a piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: -NAVIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. Hit me!

dialogues.speaker: HUSKY
dialogues.text: A goat dingleberry.

dialogues.speaker: BALDO
dialogues.text: A poo-poo face.

dialogues.speaker: IGGY
dialogues.text: A scum bag!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Okay... I accept it all... I'm all of those things... and more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fungus fart?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Yes! She's sensitive... She could see those qualities in me that's why she left. But I'm going to change. How?

dialogues.speaker: IGGY
dialogues.text: Read more.

dialogues.speaker: SLATS
dialogues.text: Become a more interesting person.

dialogues.speaker: BALDO
dialogues.text: Get rid of unwanted hair forever? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HUSKY
dialogues.text: Learn basic hygiene.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (quietly sighs) None of you can help me. I've got to do it alone. With his eyes toward the horizon, he wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin, bag packed, leans forlornly up against the fence, Next to him sits his dog, panting at Navin. “~ NAVIN (to the dog) This is not going to be easy, Shithead. We've been together a long time. But I've got to head on down that road, . (tears well up in Navin's eyes) .. and there'll be times out there when there won't be enough food for two. And I won't be able to take care of you the way you should be. Now go on... go away! The dog takes off like a rocket.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey, wait a’ second! The dog comes back. Navin goes back into his weeping.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You'll find a family who will give you a real home, with other dogs to play with. Now go on... The dog shoots off again.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Come back here! / The dog stops, then trots back to Navin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ’ NAVIN (continuing) . with loving little kids and a warm fireplace. I never liked you anyway. Now beat it. This time, as the dog starts to bound away, Navin leaps on him.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay, little fella, I can't stand it. You can come with me. He snaps a leash on Shithead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin is dragging the dog by the leash.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (V.C.)
dialogues.text: You'd like her, Ma... Her name is Marie Kimball... She's so white, she's gone beyond white almost to black. She's worth every pain I'll have to go through... And so, Mom, with my faithful dog leading the way... I'm out to become the man she desires. I'm only going to take jobs that lead somewhere big. Your loving son, Navin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin, dangling upside-down from a rope connected to a tree in the middle of nowhere, playing the violin. A passerby stops and reads the sign setting in the fiddle case.

dialogues.speaker: SIGN 169
dialogues.text: “Please give... serious student needs violin lessons."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 170
dialogues.text: The passerby's hand reaches in and takes a quarter from the case,  171 172 173 173x 174 175 176 rev.3/8 77.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 173
dialogues.text: EXT. AUTO GRAVEYARD - NIGHT 173x * We see a long shot of the auto graveyard, cars stacked one on another, squashed flat. In the far distance, Navin writes something on a piece of paper. As the camera moves in, Navin props up his hand-lettered sign, "Used cars, 10 cents.”

dialogues.speaker: INT, NAVIN'S SLUM APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Navin is asleep in bed, the want ads open beside him. We HEAR a CAR START UP in the garage directly below him. The NOISE, vibration and fumes wake him up. Blue smoke drifts up through the floor, Navin wakes, checks the clock, and reacts,

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I missed my interview. (he yells out the window) Mr. Hutchins! What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MR. HUTCHINS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Overslept! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutchins...! This room is supposed to fill up with fumes at nine a.m. and it's now nine-thirty!

dialogues.speaker: MR. HUTCHINS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well, excu-u-u-use me! cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is writing a letter home, In the b.g., out the window, we SEE a dark sedan driven by the Madman, come INTO VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Madman, using binoculars, spies on Navin as he writes.

dialogues.speaker: INT, CABIN
dialogues.text: reading a letter.

dialogues.speaker: MOM"
dialogues.text: "Dear Mom, sorry today's letter is a little late but Mr. Hutchins overslept. I haven't heard from Marie. Things couldn't be worse. I can only send you forty-nine cents this week as I've lost all my jobs.' (she shakes coins out of envelope) Bless his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin preparing a meal,

dialogues.speaker: MOM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘I've been eating well, though. The hospital gives out free meals of orange juice and cookies and all I have to do is give them a Pint of blood. I ate there all week three times a day. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I decided to quit when I cut myself shaving and only air came out. My rent is due, and it turns turns out Shithead is allergic to commercial dog food. About the only thing he can eat is medallions of white veal sauteed in butter with shallots, finished with white wine and lemon slices. Navin flames the dish and serves the dog.

dialogues.speaker: MOM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) I have to go now as someone is staring at nié through binoculars. Your loving son, Navin.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin glances out the window and sees the occupant of the car, The Madman gets out, pats the inside of his coat, and advances toward the apartment. Navin looks alarmed; his eyes zoom in on the Missouri plates. He panics. He flattens himself against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: / NAVIN
dialogues.text: Shithead! Attack! Attack! The dog attacks Navin.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nott Navin looks out the window in fear. He grabs a handful of popcorn and bolts out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin comes face to face with the Madman, throws the popcorn into the Madman's face and runs off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch! And he scrambles to his feet and sets off in hot pur- suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin ericers, running, out of breath, exhausted. He crouches by a steel door and quietly tests the handle. It's locked. From 0.S. we can HEAR the cautiously approaching FOOTSTEPS of the pursuer. They slow down as they reach the alley, Navin is too exhausted to move another step. Besides, he's trapped.
Johnson? He turns the corner and starts walking towards the terrified Nevin. His hand disappears inside his coat.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (sings) Whenever I feel afraid... The Madman looming overhead, hand in his coat as if to draw a weapon, The hand emerges, holding an en- velope.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: You'll have to sign for this.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I have to sign before you shoot me? Navin signs.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not going to shoot you. That was the old me... I'was mixed up at the time. I had a bad marriage and I had just stopped smoking... I'm okay now. I'm a private detective. S'‘long. Madman: walks away, back into the night, whistling a happy tune. Navin opens letter... reads.  184

dialogues.speaker: THE LETTER 184
dialogues.text: A simple, enigmatic letterhead: "The Berendo Corpora- tion, 1 Berendo Square, New York, New York." That's it, except for a handwritten note, barely legible.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (reading note) ‘Dear Mr. Johnson: Please call on me in Suite 2650 at the Century Plaza Tower in Los Angeles. I have something of great importance to impart to you.' . The signature is an unreadable scrawl .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the twenty-sixth floor.. The elevator doors open and a very hesitant Navin, dressed in a shabby jacket and tie, clutching the crumpled message, starts dow the hall to Suite 2650. He gets to the door and opens it with trepidation,

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 186
dialogues.text: thru 191

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vaguely familiar man comes out from behind a desk, dressed very well, wearing glasses with a little handle in the center. He's differant from the last time we saw him, a better haircut and a very hearty laugh. He roars at Navin for a long time. It's STANLEY FOX, the entrepreneur, formerly of Fox Enterprises.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Remember me?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: No, but don't feel bad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Fox. Stanley Fox. Remember, the gas station. Boy, you're one hard * guy to find. The glasses handle. Look -- He shows him the professional, finished model on his reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah... the glasses handle.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: We call it Opti-Grab. *

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Opti-Grab? .. *

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: "Opti" (points to eyes) from * optical and "Grab" from grabbing it.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Wow. ..Optical-Grabbing. *

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Navin my boy, we're in business. * Fifty-fifty, just like we said. And right in here (picks up envelope) I have your first check for two-hundred and fifty big ones. A broad grin crosses Navin's face.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Two-fifty? That's what Rod Shafter makes.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: That's just the beginning. There's gonna be more, lots more: *

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Wow. Can I cash this?

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: It's your money -- you can do anything you want. It's a eashier'’s check.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: That's great. I can use this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (discreetly interrupting) You have an eleven-thirty with Mr. Adams.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Navin, I gotta run.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (shows check) Thanks for this. Fox is already on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: FOX
dialogues.text: Don't thank me. You earned it. Don't let that money turn your head around. He's gone.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (shouts) Don't worry, my head is on straight. 193. INT, BANK - DAY — 193 Navin walks in and goes directly to one of the assis- tant managers, MR. COFFER. A narrow-minded bank man- ager who is wearing an Opti-Grab. :

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Sir. Coffer takes a long time to finish some paperwork, then looks up. NAVIN. (continuing) What's that on your glasses?

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Keeps the pressure off the stems. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (suavely) I have a cashier's check here... I'd like to cash it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: How much is it for?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Two hundred and fifty 'Samoans.' Navin removes the check from the envelope and, without looking, lays it on the desk. “INSERT - THE CHECK 194 It is for two hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER AND NAVIN 195
dialogues.text: Coffer picks up the check as if it were contaminated and examines it. He looks twice.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: You want to cash this?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Well, I could take fifty dollars and deposit the rest.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: (warming up) Sit right down, Mr. Johnson. Navin feels he's won the Bank of America over with his two hundred dollar deposit.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: (continuing) - I'll need a piece of identification.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (searches in his battered wallet) I have a temporary driver's license and my astronaut application card. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Coffer pokes the cards around with his finger, unwill- ing to even pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, and here's ny old 4-H membership... it's expired, though... I gotta renew it. Coffer takes the I.D. and the check and goes straight to the biggest desk in the bank. As Navin watches, a top management meeting takes place with lots of looks in his direction. Navin waves, nods and smiles. One of them, on the phone, nods approval and scribbles something on the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's-in order. Now, would you endorse this? He slides the check face-down to Navin, who signs it. Coffer initials the endorsement.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: (continuing) ..- And fill out this deposit slip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes pen in hand and turning the check over, rou- tinely starts copying the info. Navin gradually notices the magnitude of the check. We SEE only the barest change of expression. Navin looks up and slowly his head makes a 360-degree turn and clicks back into place. His face is euphoric. NOTE: Navin prefers that he not be required to do this without special effects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is reading a postcard while his wife LENORE stands by. He is wearing an Opti-Grab.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘Dear Harry: Guess what? I'm rich beyond my wildest dreams. But I haven't forgotten our deal. Here's that postcard I promised you. I bet you thought you'd never get it, huh? Your friend, forever, Navin.‘ (MORE) ote, .- (CONTINUED) ©  rev.3/5 * 86.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Lenore) This boy has integrity. He promised me a postcard. And that's why this little postcard will always have a special place... (taps his heart) ... in my heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, NAVIN'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Navin parks his new pink Mustang in front of his shabby apartment. He springs out, resplendent in a new Tyrol- ean hat with a long feather, a floor-length, white scarf, and sunglasses. He opens the trunk, the white scarf dragging in the mud, and removes two velvet paintings, a clown and a nude, and a big table lamp. Folded up in his coat pocket is a newspaper. The head- line of a small feature article is VISIBLE: "YOUNG INVENTOR STRIKES IT RICH." Shithead, wearing a cap, * sun glasses and sporting a pipe, follows Navin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS. Navin enters, carrying his paintings and lamp. He is startled. He has never received a real phone call before. He goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (yelling for all to hear) See! You get a phone call!... Yello... Who?... Mrs. Kimball... You're Marie's mom! You read about me?.,, No, I don't know where Marie is... I've been trying to contact her. Yes, I would love to know! Wait, I'll get a pencil. He hangs up the phone. While he collects a pencil and paper, it RINGS again. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) The May Company in Los Angeles... I'd be glad to... what's the message "I decided not to kill myself if you marry that carnival bum Nathan Johnson' -- I'll give it to her... ‘Bye, Mrs. Kimball. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Shithead) Shithead, I know where she is. Now I can find out why she left me... plus I can deliver this message from her mom about this carnival bum Nathan Johnson -- wait a minute... Shithead, she didn't mean Nathan Johnson... she meant Navin Johnson, that's me! So that's it! So that's why she wouldn't marry me! She didn't want her mother's blood on her hands,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin goes up to a FEMALE EMPLOYEE who, from the back, resembles Marie. Navin, ecstatic at finding his love, grabs her shoulders and spins her around. Their lips are inches apart. Navin realizes his mistake and casually asks:

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Uh, does Marie Kimball work here?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CLERK
dialogues.text: Oh, she's over there, in men's makeup. :

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: {winces) Men's makeup? Ugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rev.3/2 87. 199 200 201 202 A small crowd is watching Marie demonstrate. She has just applied a blue facial mask to a short, elderly ent, IRVING. His wife TILLIE is watching. Irving s wearing a shower cap and a smock. Navin enters and stops short at the sight of Marie.

dialogues.speaker: . MARIE
dialogues.text: Putting on Mask-O Derm took just fifteen minutes... and when we peel it off, he'll look twenty years younger, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: (looks heavenward) Allevei. (Yiddish for "Let it be so")

dialogues.speaker: MARIE

Three years ago, a design popped into my head. But I knew none of my clients could live in Sid Spector's dream. This design needed someone special, someone with vision. And when you walked into my office, I said, 'These are they! These are they!’ Mr. and Mrs. Johnson, this house is I. It is a complete living organism. There are sheets on the bed, a roast in the oven, and some fabulously wonderful people in the party room. By accepting this key, you are oromising Sid Spector that you will live a life of fun, more fun, and just when you think there's no more fun, you squeeze the fun tube that extra little bit and squish out the fun that will separate you from the ‘corn pones'. (gives Navin the key) Alice, welcome to Wonderland! (he throws open the door) Ciao!

dialogues.text: Thirty-seven. What kind of * calculator is that?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: It's not a calculator; it's an estimator, * ___and it gets close but it only costs two * dollars. People have been paying a big price for accuracy... this is good for the average guy who wants to know approximately what ten times four is. Next, a new idea in jigsaw puzzles... (takes cover off a large press-like machine) Now, as you know, Optigrab has recently purchased an original painting by Rembrandt... points to it hanging on the wall; takes the Rembrandt off the wall) What happens to the millionaire who loves puzzles but hates to buy bad reproductions? (raises press and slips painting into it) Who can he turn to? (pulls lever; the press closes on the painting) Us! Optigrab, manufacturers of the two million dollar fine-art jigsaw puzzle. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: et

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jig-sawed pieces of the painting come tumbling out of a chute; Navin throws pieces on the table.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) There's a little bit of fun for the sheik! All right, gentlemen... (sings) |

dialogues.speaker: MERRILY, LIFE IS BUT A DREAM.,.
dialogues.text: Now, all the vice-presidents... Some members join in singing.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN AND EXECUTIVES
dialogues.text: ROW, ROW, ROW YOUR BOAT... etc. Now, marketing... ROW, ROW, ROW YOUR BOAT, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie, tipsy, is seated on a sofa in front of a coffee table. On it is an empty bottle of wine and two glasses, A swarthy Latin dressed in a black "suit of lights". Navin enters, carrying his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Hi, honey.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (slightly tipsy) Oh, hi, doliface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curiously) Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Remember how you told me to take unnecessary lessons? I just took a lesson.

dialogues.speaker: LATIN INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: And a very good student, too. Adios Senora. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, good, you took Flamingo Guitar from that Flamingo... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: No, knife- throwing.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Knife-throwing's great!

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I can almost do it.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Well, let me see your stuff... He backs against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Now turn sideways and put a balloon in your mouth... Do you have a ‘ balloon? — (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Yes... He whips a full-blown balloon out of his breast pocket and clenches it between his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Throw it hard so it'll stick! MARIE ‘ (drunkenly weaving, and aiming a sinister butcher knife) One, two...three, four...five, six... ..-and she throws.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Aw, I missed. c.U. Navin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I can't do anything right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knife is through his fly; he is nailed to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Honey, you worry too much. He pulls the knife out and crosses to a five-gallon Sparkletts bottle bearing a Chateau Lafite Rothschild label; from it Navin draws a wine glass full of rich, red wine. NAVIN (con't) Do you realize that in two short months we have acquired the _..Phoniness that it takes some people a lifetime? C'mon, let's toast! (NOTE: He gets the Waterford Crystal from a paper-cup type dispenser.) .  Se cy €) 236 237 238 bev ees at 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP of Marie, radiant, her head tossed back. She is in the midst of a torrid disco dance. SHOT WIDENS TO INCLUDE the jumping party. Dancers, drinkers, etc. Marie is dancing up a storm. With her is Navin danc- ing in a stiff, lummox-like way.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (dressed in a sharp tuxedo) Those disco lessons really paid off, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is in full swing. On one wall is a giant Advent T.V. screen showing an old western movie. Navin and Marie at this point do a short, wild and stunning disco-like dance to be choreographed. They finish in a blaze of triumph. They are overapplauded and overcomplimented. "Navin baby, you're too much," "Dollface, just super!" etc.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (looks off toward Advent) Oooh, honey, here's that interview you did yesterday. (shouts) Everybody, we're going to watch Navin on the T.V. Shut off the music. Get your drinks and sit down.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Aw, nobody wants to see this.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Shhhh, there you are.

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN 238
dialogues.text: Closeup of Navin smiling. *

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: American Time News Magazine turns its probing eye on Navin Johnson, inventor of the Opti-grab, that little glasses handle that sold 10 million units in a few short months. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Featured on the covers of Time, Newsweek and many other major periodicals. CUTS of celebrities on magazine covers sporting Opti- grab.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mr. Johnson, you've become a millionaire overnight... Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Who is Navin Johnson? Well, Navin is a complex personality as are most of the small breed of modern day Renaissance millionaires... PICTURES of Navin being interviewed CONTINUE ON the SCREEN in CUTS. Through the following, Navin charac- terizes the Announcer's descriptions.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The interview with Mr. Johnson went on for about fifteen minutes and throughout it all, Mr. Johnson was charming, incisive, self- effacing, animated and highly emotional. Steve pantomimes above. Omitted 239

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: We had planned to show you the entire Johnson interview, however, when we returned to our studio our news department informed us of a sensational development in the Johnson story.... ° It seems a croup of irate citizens lead by the celebrity Mr. Carl Reiner has initiated a class action suit against Mr. Johnson and his Opti- - Grab. Here's what Mr, Reiner said today at a press conference. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AND PODIUM
dialogues.text: CARL is staring cross-eyed INTO CAMERA. In front of him are a hundred microphones on a podium or desk.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: When Opti-Grab came out, I thought it was the greatest * thing ever, and I bought a pair. And this is the result... He indicates his crossed-eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CON'T)
dialogues.text: That little handle is like a magnet; * your eyes are constantly drawn to it, and you end up cock-eyed. And as a director I am constantly using my eyes and the Opti-Grab device has caused irreparable harm to my career. Let me show you a clip from my latest picture, where my faulty depth per- ception kept me from yelling 'cut' at the proper time.

dialogues.speaker: A FILM CLIP 242
dialogues.text: rolls'on the SCREEN of a car driving off a cliff and rolling off it. As the car is about twenty feet over the cliff, we HEAR CARL YELL "CUT." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: If I had yelled cut in time, those actors would be alive today. That's why I am spearheading the ten million dollar class action suit against Mr. Johnson and his irresponsible selling of a product he didn't even test on prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON the party crowd. They are sturined. A couple of the partygoers remove their glasses to reveal crossed eyes. Navin smiles sickly. The partygoers drift off with excuses. "Boy, it's ten after seven," "Another phony..." "Nouveau Riche..." “He got what. he deserved," "He made my mother cock- eyed." This last man is being restrained and dragged off.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Honey, why the gloom; this is not the end of the rainbow... I'm Navin Johnson... inventor. I've got art jigsaw puzzles... the the the ear movies. This is a parking ticket to me. Only instead of five dollars, it's ten million. -

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (crying) I don't care about losing the money; it's losing all the stuff.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: We're not going to lose our stuff. This is America. I'm going to receive a fair trial from an impartial jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN ACROSS a row of twelve jurors. They are all cross-eyed. The FOREMAN rises.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: We find for the plaintiff. *

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE 246
dialogues.text: We only SEE the side of his head, with Navin in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I award to Mr. Reiner and the other nine million nine hundred, eighty-seven thousand six hundred fifty-two plaintiffs, the full amount of the suit. Navin takes out his pocket estimator and calculates.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: But, you honor, that's between 99 cents and a $1.15 per person approximately. I'll be wiped out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE 247
dialogues.text: This time we SEE his face. He is cross-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (he bangs the gavel, missing the block) Court is adjourned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin sits at a desk, drinking. We SEE movers in the b.g. carting out a sofa. There are piles of envelopes on one side of the desk, and piles of blank checks on the other. Navin is writing diligently. He is wearing a short robe and is looking a mess.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Pay to the order of Mrs. Wilbur Stark, one dollar and nine cents. Signed Navin R. Johnson. He puts it in the envelope, licks it, stamps it and adds it to the stack. He starts another.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mr. Iron Balls McGinty... (suddenly he wheels around) What...? There is nothing and no one there.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: enters. the first He stands ankles. She comes

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) One dollar and... (he takes another drink) . nine... (he's crazy) Huh? What's this?! Lint...! This lint. It's driving me erazy! 249 She is wearing the gingham dress she wore in bedroom scene. She is crying slightly.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Why are you crying?... and why are you wearing that old dress?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Because I just heard a song on the radio that reminded me of the way we were.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: “What was it?

dialogues.speaker: . MARIE
dialogues.text: "The Way We'Were.' Look at us... we've hit. bottom.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no... maybe you hit bottom, but I haven't hit bottom yet. up. We SEE his pants are down around his

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I've got a ways to go. And besides, I'm gonna bounce back and when I get to the top again, I'll buy you a diamond so big it'll make you puke! to him and speaks warmly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTE
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, I don't 7 to puke.

dialogues.speaker: RE,
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't want wealth. I want you like you used to be. What happened to that man?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Me? What happened to the girl I fell in love with? The girl who believed in me. Well there's plenty of places I can go?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Well gol The sooner you're out of my life, the sooner I can go back to being that wonderful girl in the gingham dress that you sang the Thermos song tol

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Well I'm going then and I don't need anything. Just this ashtray... (picks it up) ... and that's it... the ashtray and this remote control... (picks it up) the ashtray and the remote control and that's it... And this paddle game... {picks up paddle) . and. that's it... and this chair. * By this time Navin has worked his way just outside the open front door. Marie is still inside.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: What do you think I am...some kind of Jerk? With tears in her eyes, Marie watches him go stumbling * across the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN 250
dialogues.text: She slams the door. Wham! Navin looks indignant. He turns and walks out the gates with his pants around his ankles, and his ashtray, TV remote control and paddle and chair. *  251 252 253 254 255 256 rev. 5/79 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK SHOTS of Navin trudging down a hill in Bel-Air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK SHOTS of Navin walking through crowds in Century City, looking up at Stan Fox's office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the PLATE GLASS in the lobby, we can SEE Navin shuffling across the concourse still in bathrobe, drink in hand, pants around ankles, paddle-ball in pocket. People give way to let his through as he heads into the lobby and waits for an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is stripped bare with only one empty file cabinet and a door on two saw-horses for a desk. Stan Fox is packing things in a box to go on the road. There is a meek looking young man sitting shyly in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Stan, I got some more ideas.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (elated) Yeah, yeah...Looks good, Looks good...Good luck with them...: I got a new boy -- Medford Baxter! Found him at a bus stop. Kid's a genius. He came up with a surefire money maker... Stan opens his coat to reveal a thick leather belt with pouches around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) A bible belt! Carries all your bibles! Old Testament, New Testament, King James Version, New. Revised Version, The Gay Bible, it's got everything. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's a church around your waist. Pow! “Sinner: Come on Medford. * {puts on Western Hat) There's a lot of twenty-four ninety- five out there, and it's got our name on it. Navin, one minute you're up, one minute you're down. Think of it this way...we killed two minutes!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navin exits the building and sits on a bench. There is an old magazine nearby. Navin picks it up in his delirium and stares at it. The shimmering effect on the cover changes the face of the girl into Hartounian's face.

dialogues.speaker: HARTOUNIAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... And some day when you're at the bottom of the barrel, and you're walking around with your pants down around your ankles, you'll take out this little piece of paper I'm giving you and you'll read something that'll take the pain away.

dialogues.speaker: ON NAVIN 258
dialogues.text: Navin takes his wallet out of his pants and finds the tattered envelope. He opens it and we SEE it as he unfolds dramatically the piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: PIECE OF PAPER 258A
dialogues.text: It reads: "For a good time, call Trudy, 555-1212."

dialogues.speaker: 258B ON NAVIN 2583
dialogues.text: Navin looks up.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (Calls) Trudy...! Trudy...!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 258B
dialogues.text: An elderly lady carrying a striped thermos and a lunch * bag, passes Navin. He follows the lady around a corner. The camera stays put on the empty scene, and moments late the woman appears carrying Navin's chair, remote control, etc. Navin appears with the thermos and wanders off forlornly.

dialogues.speaker: OMMITTED 266
dialogues.text: Navin, in tattered bum clothes, looks at his watch rue- fully, umstraps it and enters the shop. A moment later, he steps out of the shop carrying a beat-up sax- ophone. He looks puzzled, puts it under his arm and walks off. EXT. PIZZA SHOP - DAY 266 a Navin approaches the window and watches a pretty young girl taking a pizza from an oven. As she is cutting it, she feels Navin's eyes on her and looks up. -He looks so Pathetic that her maternal instincts take hold. She wants to do for this man what the girl in Midnight Express did for her lover in the Turkish prison. She refers to her lips; Naving shakes his head no. She thrusts her breasts forward and shimmys them. Navin says no; he instead point to the pizza. She understands, and with great compassion squishes the pizza against the wall while Navin tries to eat the pizza against the glass. 267 Omitted . 267 268

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: Trumpet solo of "What'll I Do" Navin watches as a bum rushes out into the traffic and cleans a car windshield with a rag. The driver gives the bum a coin, A beautiful, gleaming Ferrari pulls to a stop at the light near Navin. He runs up to the car removing a filthy rag from his coat pocket, and in an attempt to clean the windshield, smears a thick film of oil and food all over the windshield, totally ob- scuring the driver's view. Navin holds out his hand for a tip as the car speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are back to the scene on page one. The rain has stopped. Navin lays in the gutter talking INTO the CAMERA. The theatre is letting out.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: So that's it. It's an old story, one that you've probably heard before, but I never thought it would happen to me. rev. 5/79 * 125. 269 270 He takes a swig from the thermos. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to end the movie, and then we START TO FADE OUT, when a voice interrupts. A Big, black sedan pulls up. A BLACK DRIVER pokes his head out the window.

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: Hey, any of you bums ever heard of Navin R. Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: (a drunken voice) I've heard of him!

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: Born in Mississippi? “NAVIN Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: He once had wealth, power, and the love of a beautiful woman?

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: Inventor of the Opti-grab? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I was just telling these guys...!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Son!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: Daddy...! (Navin kisses Dad) Be looks in the car. NAVIN (con't) Mom... (kisses Mom) Elvira...the whole family... Taj:

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: (holds Navin off) Don't kiss me! Marie steps out of the back seat wearing a white dress.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Navin? He goes to embrace her, hesitates, and then takes her with abandon, and licks his face.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I called them the night you left. NAVIN ; How did you ever find me?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I don't know. This is the first place we looked.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: We're takin’ both of you home. You're going to live with us.

dialogues.speaker: TAT
dialogues.text: Turns out, Dad's a financial genius.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: All I did was take the money you sent us and embarked on a periodic investment in a no- load mutual fund. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leveraged his ass deep into soy beans and cocoa futures.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIRA
dialogues.text: Right on!

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I picked up this thermos for you. I would kiss you but I'm too dirty.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Dirt doesn't bother me...but the smell does. Phew!

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You better get back with the dog until we hose you down.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I love you, Navin.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Open all the windows.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, every one of them. More weeping and embracing as they get into the car and a the car drives off...

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was so glad to be going home. I remembered that last day when I Sang and danced with my family on the porch of the old house. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Replay of the original scene of Navin and family dancing. on the porch to the tune of "Pick A Bale 0' Cotton".

dialogues.speaker: NAVIN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But things changed, and with all the additions to the family, we had to tear down the old house, even though we loved it and build a bigger one.

dialogues.speaker: 127A,
dialogues.text: a 270B EXT. PORCH OF NEW HOUSE - DAY 270B - Cut to exact angle of original scene, revealing the famil all dressed in white dancing and singing on the porch and in front of an exact copy of the original shack twice the size.
